newsitem.title: JAPAN: U.S. Treasuries not excessively vulnerable - Lindsey.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Treasuries not excessively vulnerable - Lindsey.

text.p: Former Federal Reserve Board Governor Lawrence Lindsey told Reuters Financial Television in an interview on Friday that he did not think the U.S. Treasury market was extra vulnerable to a sell-off following recent comments by the Japanese prime minister on U.S. Treasuries.

Asked about the level of U.S. Treasury bonds and whether U.S. Treasuries were vulnerable to a large sell-off after Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto commented in late June that Japan was tempted to sell its holdings of U.S. securities in the past, he said: "People should buy bonds wherever they want to buy bonds."
"Japanese investors, German investors, and also central banks around the world buy U.S. Treasuries not to be kind to America, but because they think it is in their own self-interest," he said.
"I think as long as people are motivated by self-interest, then that's the rule of the market and how we should live with it. I don't think there is excessive vulnerability now."

Regarding the collapse of the price of gold, Lindsey said: "There is a lot of central bank selling. Central banks hold substantial portions of gold." He said it was not so much a supply-demand factor that was causing the price of gold to fall, but rather a change in the attitude of central banks.
